Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28,.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28, the Court may modify custody orders if a material and substantial change in circumstances affects the best interests of the child.

Gediman v. Gediman, 202 Mass. 209 (1909).proposition: In determining whether to modify custody, the overriding consideration is the best interests of the child.
Gediman v. Gediman, 202 Mass. 209 (1909).case_name: Strong v. Carver Cotton Gin Co.
Gediman v. Gediman, 202 Mass. 209 (1909).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns patent royalties, implied contractual arrangements, and the power of a trial judge to report a case. It does not involve custody, family law, or any discussion of the best interests of the child standard. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about modifying custody based on the child’s best interests.
Gediman v. Gediman, 202 Mass. 209 (1909).relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion anywhere in the provided opinion text of custody, children, or the best interests of the child; the case instead addresses termination of an implied royalty arrangement and related evidentiary and procedural issues.

El Chaar v. Chehab, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 50.raw_text: El Chaar v. Chehab, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 501 (2010)
El Chaar v. Chehab, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 50.proposition: In determining whether to modify custody, the overriding consideration is the best interests of the child.
El Chaar v. Chehab, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 50.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion concerns speedy trial rights and Rule 36 computations in a criminal case; it does not address custody, domestic relations, or standards for modifying custody orders. There is no discussion of the “best interests of the child” or any custody-related framework. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the proposition about the standard for modifying custody.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Evidence of instability or substance use by a parent is relevant to the Court’s determination of a material change in circumstances.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses factors relevant to a best-interests custody analysis—such as stability of each parent’s home, work schedule, and efforts to alienate the child from the other parent—but it does not address parental instability or substance use as evidentiary considerations. There is no mention of substance use at all, and while the court does consider instability in living circumstances and caregiving arrangements, it does so in the context of best-interests at an initial custody determination, not in terms of proving a material change in circumstances. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that, after the move to Oregon, Jill lived in four different residences in less than one year and had ‘no less than five different care providers,’… In addition, Rose accepted a residency in Michigan, a State where she has no ties… The judge found that a move to Michigan would put Jill ‘in an unfamiliar environment with new caregivers and… medical providers’ while Rose worked ‘extraordinary long hours as a medical resident for the next four years,’ and that Rose had demonstrated that she cannot manage child care without significant support.”

Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007)
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.proposition: Parental alcohol use that impairs judgment or creates an unsafe environment for the child supports modification of custody arrangements.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss parental alcohol use at all, nor any substance-related impairment of judgment or unsafe environment. The case is about whether a biological father can be denied custody or required to share guardianship absent a finding of unfitness, focusing on parental fitness, bonding with guardians, and best-interests analysis. It therefore provides no authority for the specific proposition that alcohol use impairing judgment or creating an unsafe environment supports modification of custody.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “Custody of a child belongs to a parent unless that parent is unfit… The question, then, is how to balance a parent’s capacity to care adequately for a child (i.e., his or her ‘fitness’) with that child’s ‘best interests,’ given the child’s current circumstances… [I]f returning custody to the [biological] parent[] would be seriously detrimental to the welfare of the child, then the parent[] could be considered to be unfit.” (70 Mass. App. Ct. at 578-82).

Allen v. Allen, 93 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (.raw_text: Allen v. Allen, 93 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (2018)
Allen v. Allen, 93 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (.proposition: The Court has full discretion to impose specific conditions on parenting time, including supervised visitation or restrictions, to ensure the safety of the child.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: A parent’s right to visitation does not supersede the child’s need for a safe and stable living environment.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The case concerns grandparent (nonparent) visitation over the objection of fit parents, not a parent’s right to visitation. Its core holding is that parental autonomy is fundamental but may be overridden only upon a showing that denying grandparent visitation will cause the child significant harm; it does not state or analyze that a parent’s visitation rights yield to a child’s need for a safe and stable home. The opinion focuses on state interference with parental decision-making, not on limiting a parent’s own visitation in favor of the child’s safety or stability.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “To obtain visitation, the grandparents must rebut the presumption. The burden of proof will lie with them to establish, by a preponderance of the credible evidence, that a decision by the judge to deny visitation is not in the best interests of the child. More specifically, to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare.”

Adoption of Nancy, 443 Mass. 512 (2005).proposition: The Massachusetts Department of Children and Families (DCF) standards prioritize close parental relationships, but not at the cost of endangering the child.
Adoption of Nancy, 443 Mass. 512 (2005).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests standard, parental unfitness, termination of rights, and children’s wishes, but it does not describe or interpret Massachusetts DCF/DSS “standards” as prioritizing close parental relationships. Its focus is on stability, safety, and permanency when a parent’s conduct (here, chronic alcoholism and noncompliance) endangers the children. While the result is consistent with not sacrificing child safety for parental contact, the case does not itself articulate the specific principle that DCF standards prioritize close parental relationships subject to a safety limit.
Adoption of Nancy, 443 Mass. 512 (2005).relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the Committee for Public Counsel Services (CPCS) standards, or in our cases, recommending that children be asked to express an opinion on what is in their best interests, as that is essentially a legal judgment. … There can be no doubt that the judge’s termination order was based on her assessment of the over-all damage that the father’s noncompliance had wrought on the girls’ lives, and her determination that they should be protected from the uncertainty of repeated litigation and their father’s destructive behavior in the future.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: As modifying custody falls within the Court’s equitable powers, the Court has the authority to fashion relief that prioritizes the safety and well-being of the child over rigid adherence to prior orders.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is about initial and temporary custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C and the primacy of the child’s best interests; it does not frame those powers as part of a generalized ‘equitable’ modification authority, nor does it discuss modifying custody orders as an exercise of broad equitable powers overriding prior orders. The court instead emphasizes statutory standards (best interests and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a)) and criticizes the temporary order but expressly notes its validity is not before the court. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition regarding the court’s equitable power to modify custody orders and fashion relief beyond prior orders.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 209C, § 10 (a)… gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’ … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”
